description: From Middle English wresten, wrasten, wræsten, from Old English wrǣstan (“to twist forcibly, wrench”), from Proto-Germanic *wraistijaną, (compare Proto-Germanic *wrīhaną (“to turn, wind; to cover, envelop”), *wrīþaną (“to weave, twist”), Old Norse reista (“to bend, twist”)), from a derivative of Proto-Indo-European *wreiḱ-, *wreyḱ- (“to bend, twist”), *wreyt- (“to bend”). See also writhe, wry.
The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: The act of wresting; a wrench or twist; distortion.
(music) A key to tune a stringed instrument.
(obsolete, rare) Short for saw wrest (“a hand tool for setting the teeth of a saw, determining the width of the kerf”); a saw set.

verbs.description: wrest (third-person singular simple present wrests, present participle wresting, simple past and past participle wrested)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To obtain by pulling or violent force.
examples: He wrested the remote control from my grasp and changed the channel.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To distort, to pervert, to twist.
(transitive, music) To tune with a wrest, or key.

description: Possibly a variant of wrist: see the quotation. Wrist is also derived from *wrīþaną (“to weave, twist”), from a derivative of Proto-Indo-European *wreiḱ-, *wreyḱ- (“to bend, twist”), *wreyt- (“to bend”).

entries.meaning: A partition in a water wheel by which the form of the buckets is determined.

description: A misspelling of rest, probably influenced by wrest (etymology 1, verb and noun).

entries.meaning: (agriculture, dated, dialectal) A metal (formerly wooden) piece of some ploughs attached under the mouldboard (the curved blade that turns over the furrow) for clearing out the furrow; the mouldboard itself.
